Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What do drugs do? Choices:  A: damage B: cloud mind C: lower i.q D: cause illness E: cause accidents<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer A; D: cause illness because it lowers IQ and causes accidents<n><n>## What is a binary tree?<n>A tree in which each node has two children that is, a binary tree can have, for instance, three, six, eight, or thirty-two nodes at any point.<n><n>## Binary Tree Walk<n>A *depth first* walk of a tree consists in visiting a number of nodes until visiting each and every node of the tree. The set all vertices of the tree represents a binary tree of depth 1.<n><n>## Binary tree with nodes of depth 1. This tree has 2 nodes and it visits level 6 because the tree is in a depth first walk from level 1 till level 6<n><n>## Level order traversal(LOT)<n>The standard algorithm for level order traversal visits every node exactly once, in the order in which those nodes occur as branches in the level order traversal of the tree.<n><n><n><img src="assets/img/tree/T7.jpg" alt=""><n><n><n><n><n>### Input <n><img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pandianramachandran/Project-1-Trees/master/assets/img/tree_node.png" alt=""><n>### Answer B<img src="assets.jpg" alt="T1"><n>### Demonstartion<n><img src="09072018200848.gif" alt="T2"><n><n><n>## Heap<n>Heaps are binary trees. The nodes in a heap are numbered from 0 to (n−1), with 0 on the left side, the root has rank of n (0 = 0, 1, 2,..., n−1). If we replace rank with weight, then a binary heap is a complete binary tree such that in every node left < to > (right) and (right) < to > left.<n><n><img src=assets/img/tree.png width=30%><n><n><img src = assets/img/heap.png width=50%><n><n>## LRU<n>A key, value pair is removed from the cache when its Least-Recently-Used (LRU) and least commonly used (LRU). LRU is

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:The student needed to  get some new pencils, where did he go? Choices:  A: store B: classroom C: backpack D: cabinet E: teacher<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>```python<n>class Solution:<n>    # def isSubtree(self, p, q) -> bool:<n>    #     if (p == p.value and q == q.value):<n>    #         return True<n>    #     else:<n>    #         return self.isSubtree(p.right, q.left) or self.isSubtree({p.value}, q.value) or self.is<n>    # Subtree(q.value, p.right)<n>    <n>    def isSubtree(node): # pylint:disable=arguments-differ<n>        is_left_root = (not node.left)<n>        if not is_left_root and node == (node.left.left) or node == (node.right.left):<n>            return is_left_root<n>        else:<n>            return self.is_leaf_node(node.left) or self._is_leaf_node((node.right))<n>    <n>    def _is_leaf_node (tree):<n>        return (not tree.value == tree.left and not tree.value == tree)<n>    <n>    """<n>    def isSubTree(self, node):<n>        is_left = len(node.left) == 0 and len(node.right) == 0<n>        if is_left:<n>            return is_leaf_node(leaf_node)<n>        else:<n><n>            if self.left_node(leaf, node, right_node):<n>                return self.is_subtree(leaf) or self.left_node_of_right(right, leaf, right_node)<n>            elif self.right_node_of_leaf(right_node, leaf):<n>                if self.left_subtree_of_leaf(leaf, leaf_node) and self.right_subtree_of(<n>                    right, leaf_node):<n>                    return self.is_right_node_of(node, leaf, right, right_node, left_node)<n>            else:<n>                return self.left_sub_tree(left, node, left_node) and self._is_leaf(right)<n><n>    def _left_subtree_is_right(self, leaf, node): <n>        """<n>        :param leaf: leaf value<n>

Choices:  A: active B: hunger C: in motion D: wakefulness E: lay down<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>ans = input().strip()<n>if ans == 'C':<n>        print("yes")<n>else:<n>        print("no")<n>```<n>### Input: What is the most dangerous animal? Choices: 1: lion 2: bear 3: crocodile Choices:  T: tiger B: bison C: cobra D: dolphins<n><n>### Response<n>```python<n>ans2 = input().strip()[0].casefold()<n>if ans2 == '2':<n>        print("Bison")<n>else:<n>    print("Cobra")<n>```<n>## Contribute<n><n>Welcome to your first PR<n><n>This is an example of a pull request that was made for class instruction<n><n>You can also fork this and contribute to the repo or this is a place to learn about how to do that.<n><n>## Requirements<n><n>* This is a Python application<n><n>## Contact Information<n><n>Send any questions regarding to [**Patrick_Huang***](https://github.com/Patrick-Huang)<n>

This will help the computer do very small tasks more easily so other computers can handle other tasks like A.I.<n><n>In general A.I. is helpful to people. If someone wanted to send text to another person and said machine can translate what was said. I can imagine the people sending and receiving the messages. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Two friends wanted to spend a quiet evening together, what did they go see? Choices:  A: wedding B: friend's house C: internet cafe D: movie E: restaurant<n><n>### Response:		Movie<n><n>### Solution<n><n>``` javascript<n>var answer<n>answer = input.reduce((answers, i) => {<n><n>  if(answers[i]) {<n>  answers[i].forEach(v => ans.push(v))<n>  ans.push(1)<n>  return ans.sort((a, b) => (a > b)? 1 : -1)<n>  <n>  }<n>  return answers<n><n>})<n><n>console.log(answers.map((a, i) => i+1))<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Where are floors kept clean for holy purposes? Choices:  A: restaurant B: basement C: all buildings D: carpet E: synagogue<n><n>### Response:		<n>Dear Jane,<n><n>It sounds like you’re trying to remember the answer to a trivia question. If you’re not sure of the answer, you might try Googling it. That will give you more options and some supporting evidence.<n><n>I hope that’s it!<n><n>### Examples of Response: <n><n>```text<n>> I am not sure what you mean. Choices:  A: health center B: vagina C: emergency room D: drawer E: medicine cabinet<n><n>### Response:		<n>You can get them from a health center. health centers are free but don't have any contraceptive options. You can get them from a country. Countries provide you with options but have long waiting times and usually do not offer the option you want. You can get them on the internet. The internet has all sorts of things but most of them are illegitimate and do not contain real contraceptives. You can get them free from emergency rooms. Free care at emergency rooms are hard to get so you might have to wait in for days and in the meanwhile contracting a disease. You can get them for as low as $1 from the medical cabinet.

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:John had a lot of respect for Jill, but not many other people did.  She faced a lot of what? Choices:  A: ignoring B: being rude C: disparagement D: contumely E: uncertainty<n><n>### Response:		A: B: C: D: E:<n><n>### Reason:<n><n><n><n>## Part 2:<n>### Instruction<n>Give examples of things which can be defined as 'intricate' or 'complex', things that are 'intricate' and 'complex' but not'simple', 'basic', and 'primitive'. Do not include examples of things which have more complex parts which may look intricate or complex but are not intricate or complex themselves (things such as subatomic particles, which make up atoms).<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: Complex things are intricate. Answer: A: True<n><n>### Demosntration:<n>Input: Simple things can be intricate. Answer: B: False<n><n>### Demoscntration:<n>Intricate: a book<n><n>### Demonscncotraion:<n>Intricate, not complex: An incomplex book.<n><n>### Comment<n>A: An intricate thing cannot be basic, but a complex thing can be basic. <n><n>C: The thing called 'intricate' has this meaning in the sentence given, but not as an abstract concept. <n><n>E: Complex things are more basic than intricate, more intricate things are more complex than simple. <n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What treatment might an old time doctor have tried to accomplish with leeches? Choices:  A: heart transplant B: distance himself C: perform surgery D: study medicine E: let blood<n><n>### Response:		Choosing B from the choices above. the doctor might have use it for distance or study medicine<n><n>### Explanation:<n>```python <n>import sys<n><n>#asking user to type 'Q' for quit<n>if (sys.stdin.isatty()):<n>    print('(Q for quit)')<n>    question_choice = input ('\tQuit (Q for Q) : \t')<n>    if (question_choice == 'Q'):<n>        print('I will try more later.....')<n>        sys.exit()<n>```<n><n>### Input <n>* You can use a variable that contains "Q" for quit. The example above creates 'question_choice' as an input (question).<n><n>### Exampl<n>

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Billy bounced the ball off the wall.  There was a target on the wall for him to bounce against.  Where might he be? Choices:  A: pool table B: toy box C: playroom D: park E: closet<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>![response][response-img]<n><n>### Explanation:  <n><n>This is a pretty easy response. First you will find the position of this string by splitting on a space and using.split. Split() will return a list of strings where a is the character, and b is the other character in the character string. Then, you would do this:<n><n>```<n>print((position_list[0] + position_list[1].split()[0]))<n>```<n><n>### References:<n><n><n>*  : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w45ZD6BhvNw&t=404s (1)<n><n><n><n> <n>[response-img]: https://github.com/zhang-hongfeng/CS-A100/blob/master/Week-4/Week4_response.png<n>[response]: https://github.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What would you normally expect a cat to say? Choices:  A: see king B: hello C: meow D: drink water E: live many years<n><n>### Response:		<n>* The code would look like this:<n><n>```<n>@param question (String)<n>def respond(question):<n>```<n><n>* Then you would have a `while True:` loop and inside of it, a `input = int(raw_input(userInput)):` where `userInput` is whatever the user put.<n>* Next, you would use these variables to test if the input made sense:<n><n>```<n>if userInput > 0 :<n>	print("Invalid input!")<n>	return<n>elif userInput == 0 :<n>	return<n>```<n>* After, you would have to get a `Choice` variable that would have all the options. After, you would loop through all the options, and if the user input matched with it, you would print out the response.<n><n>### Code<n><n>```<n>import random<n>answer=input("What would you like to buy?")<n><n>while True:<n>    input = int(raw_ input(name))<n><n>    if input >0 :<n>        print("Invalid input!") <n>        continue<n>    elif input == 0 : <n>        return<n><n>if answer == "car":<n>     num = random.randint(1, 10)<n>     if num == 2: <n>       print("20  bucks")<n>     elif num == 3:                 <n>       print("14 bucks")<n>     else<n>      print("5  bucks")<n>if answer =="soda" :<n>     print("1.75")<n><n>```<n><n>### Reflection:<n><n>* First of all, there were no errors in the code. However, when I went to make all the while True loop, I forgot one thing. To loop through the choices. There are 2 parts for the loops.<n><n><n>* Another way that I could have done this was, instead of having the user input, I could have put in a few options and see if the user input any of those things. But there are a lot of advantages and disadvantages but choosing the way of having the user input it. Also the other way would be more simple, but not the best option.<n><n><n>* In general, I feel like I could work on writing better code because even though this was pretty good code, it would be better to see if there are any other ways to make the code even more

Her favorite __4__ is the alphabet song, because she learned it when she was __5__ years old. The easiest thing that she teaches is the multiplication table, __6__. The hardest thing that she teaches us is writing her name, __7__. I like math better then the alphabet song.<n><n>#### Question 1: <n>- 4: She never tells us which subject is her favourite.<n><n>#### Question: <n>- 5: She learned it when she was five years old.<n><n>#### Q: <n>- 6: It is the easiest thing that she teach us.<n><n>#### Q3: <n>-7: The hardest thing that we learn from her is to write her name.<n>The multiplication table is the __easiest__ thing she teaches us?<n><n>---<n> #### Blank<n>In my book there are two parts: the first part is about some kids at their summer camp. They wanted them to be __4__. They tried to find jobs, so they could take care of the girls. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Where is a monkey likely to be found in the rainforest? Choices:  A: tree tops B: rain forest C: zoological gardens D: great outdoors E: zoo<n><n>### Response:		<n>In the rainforest monkeys are rarely found sleeping in a tree top. Monkey are more frequently found in the ground covering rainforest floors or up in the foliage at the top of the canopies. Monkeys also visit the forest floor in search of food and water holes.<n><n>### Input:"Wow, is your dog cute!" Where does your dog often have friends come over? Choices:  C: A: your neighbors house B: your home E: D: school<n><n>### Response:"Oh thanks! You should visit! My dog spends most of her time playing in our back yard or on the beaches which is why she is so well behaved,"<n><n>### Input-Your dog, Molly, is excited because you have been invited her to go to a dog park. What is a dog park? Choices:  D: A: Dog owners meeting place B: A: Dogs playing place  C: B: A shelter <n><n>### Response-Dog parks are a favorite of some people's dogs. They provide a space for dogs to play while dog owners get a chance to socialize with other pet owners while their dog enjoying time with it's own kind and getting fresh exercise.<n><n>### Response to "Where do most birds live?" (If it is true a bird has wings, the response will be "In the air" otherwise "On the ground"). Choices:  D:"In the air"  B: A: "On the ground" E: C: "They live in the bird-house"<n><n>### Response, If the bird lives in the air or a bird-house, response will be: They live in the air.<n><n>### If the bird live on the ground, response will be: This is false.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Where is a ferret getting lots of attention likely to be found? Choices:  A: trouser leg B: sick bay C: own home D: petting zoo E: mother's hair<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Choices:  A: sick bay  B: mother's hair  C: own home  D: petting zoo  E: trouser leg<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>Choices should be in the same order as the input and each choice should be a different combination of letters from the question's input.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>Choices(A):  sick bay,  mother's hair  <n>Choices(B):  own home,petting zoo,country,alaska  <n>Choices(C):  sick bay,petting zoo,park,university  <n>Choices(D):  sick bay,country,trouser leg,alaska  <n>Output for each row should be followed by a new line.<n>You can choose one of four ways to display choice letters, based on how it fits your purpose.<n><n>1. Each choice is displayed at the same position where it is in input, from A to Z. For example,  C: mother's hair is positioned where E: country was displayed.<n><n>2. Each choice is displayed next to the letter that is in the same position it is in the choices' input. For example, C: mother's is displayed next to B: mother's, which is its input position.<n><n>3. Each choice is displayed in a new row.<n><n>4. Each choice is displayed vertically, in columns.<n><n>As for what is displayed in the response, it depends on how you want to display your output results. See [Instruction: Answer the following multiple choice question](../instructions/question.md) and [Instruction: Write a response that appropriates a request](../instructions.md).<n><n>### Conclusion:<n><n><n>### Examples:<n><n><n>## Contributors:<n><n>[Kenji Yura 尤良乾](mailto:talk@kenyura.com)<n>

Choices:  A: opened B: closed C: found at shower D: falling down E: locked<n><n>### Response:		<n>The new kitten hadn’t gotten used to climbing on what it was allowed to, and after a good nap there was a surprise waiting for it. The bedroom door was left open for this reason. The cat was very pleased with the new found freedom to do as it wished, but it accidentally fell. It rolled over as it fell, getting more scratches in the process. If the door had been closed, this sadness could have been avoided.<n><n>### Sample Response<n>```<n>When an animal is not familiar with what they are allowed to do in each room, it can cause confusion. When this confusion occurs, the owner wants to make sure their life gets back to the normal state, so they will generally try to close off areas that can be a problem for a cat. In this case, the owner didn’t follow through in trying to prevent problems, and accidently fell over because the door was accidentally open. Had the owner followed through in protecting the cat, the cat might not have fallen.<n>```<n><n>### Exercise A <n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Exercises that are solved:<n><n>* [Exercise](http://www.repl.it/@SnowyCoder/A/002)<n>

When you do this, the teacher cannot evaluate if you understand what they were saying or if you have your facts correct. The most important part of any answer is whether they can understand what you are saying and whether you are correct.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Where can you purchase food and eat it at tables? Choices:  A: house B: fast food restaurant C: library D: conference E: paper<n><n>### Response:		Input: Where can you purchase food and EAT it at tables? Choice: A: house<n><n>### Explanation:<n>We are not allowed to change any letters in between any of the words, nor can we replace letters. You can only replace with the same letter after it.<n><n>### Expected Output: <n>**Input**: Where do humans go to be in nature?<n><n>**Choice A**:<n>**Correct Option**: Movie Theatres - Humans go to _movie theatres_ to be in nature.<n><n>**Choice B**:<n>**Corrupt Option**: Parks Humans go to _parks_ to be in nature<n><n>**Choice C**: (Slightly incorrect)<n>**Correct Option:** Universities Humans go to _universities_ to be in nature (But humans are not in nature to study)<n><n>**Choice D**: (Not an option)<n><n>**Choice E**: (Not an Option)<n><n>**Choice_D:** Humans go to _Alaska_ to be in nature, but Alaska should have been Alaska and not Alaksa.<n><n>### Output:<n>**Input**: where can you purchase food and have it there at tables?<n><n>**Choice 1**: Humans go to _house_ to purchase food _and_ eat it at tables? <n><n>**Choice 2**: Humans go _to university_ to purchase food and eat it _there_ at tables?<n><n>### Expectation:<n>If you do not have a table in your house for food why should that choice be marked as correct?<n><n>*This challenge should pass all tests if the input and choices are passed in correctly. This challenge should pass or fail based on the given text for the choice and the response.*<n>

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What is the biggest speech in the capital? Choices:  A: each state B: gettysburg address C: state of union D: each country E: europe<n><n>### Response:		<n>In the capital city, what do humans do to get close to nature and get relaxed?<n><n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question. <n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: Why do humans give speeches at the capital? Choices a: for peace b: for war c: to talk about important stuff d: to see everyone e: to meet everyone <n><n>### Answer:<n>Humans give speeches at the Capital for what purpose?<n><n><n>## The final task is a multi-step process. Write a script that will ask for steps to follow, complete each one and provide a result. <n>For example, the script for finding your friend's phone in the house using the process of elimination might be <n><n>The script might be<n><n>input: how many rooms in house<n><n>choose one of the rooms: answer.<n><n>If you have to walk from room to room:<n>input: how many sets of steps in house.<n>repeat the same process but with more sets.<n><n>if you have got to every room or you are near the end the answer would be my friends friend.<n><n>## The final step is to present what you learned. Use the following example to help you create your own video.<n><n><n>### Expectations: Your script should be written, proof read and should use the following example as a guideline for presentation.<n><n>### The video should be in the following order.<n><n>### First the video should explain in your own words, the difference between <n><n>### The second in your own words, what you have learned about scripting.<n><n>### In the <n>### The third and most important part is to teach others how to create a script. Your script should teach how to complete this assignment.<n><n>### Teaching your script should include the following:<n><n>### The task to do<n><n>### A demonstration of what your script does<n><n>### A proof that it works<n><n>### A prompt for a command that proves your script works<n><n>### Example video script:<n><n>### Input : In what country are you from?<n><n>### Choice : Canada<n><n>### Instuction : <n><n>### Output : <n><n>## The most important part of this video is to teach others how they can complete this project.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:In what place could you find air that has been breathed by many people recently? Choices:  A: charming B: space shuttle C: house D: train station E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>You could either find air that has been recently breathed by many people:<n><n>- At a train station - This air has often been recently breathed by large groups of people. As people board a train they often leave behind a lot of carbon dioxide, which could fill up a train station if not filtered through air circulation and ventilation.<n><n>- On a subway - As humans commute to and leave work, they all breathe air that has been previously breathed by numerous other humans over the course of the day. Some humans that take public transport may breathe the same air as other humans who ride the same route every day.<n><n>- In a shopping centre or mall - In a mall’s central atrium, humans will frequently pass through a large number of doors for many years continuously rebreathing the same air.<n><n>- A museum, library, restaurant or bookstore - These buildings commonly have high ceilings allowing air to circulate around a lot of people for a long period of time. This gives the air a chance to meet many other humans before finally leaving the building.<n><n>- In an office building or apartment block - In these buildings air is circulated around many areas over many hours each day. This allows the same air to flow past many humans over that course of day. Air can be breathed in by large groups of people over the course of time in an office building.<n><n>- On the surface of a planet - On Earth air is circulated constantly by the wind and water cycle. Humans are breathing fresh air from places that are many thousands of kilometres away from them when they breathe.<n><n>

Please choose either A or B below<n><n>Demonstration:<n><n>Input: Please explain the correct choice.<n><n>Examples:<n>Input: What did you do last night?<n>Demonstration Example<n><n>Example 1. You worked out last night.<n><n>Example 2. You slept last night.<n><n>### Response<n>Input: How do you wake up in the morning?<n><n>Examples: <n>You sleep all night.<n>You are awake.<n>You sleep during the day.<n>You are not tired in the morning.<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: When should you go to the gym? Choices: A: Before you go to work B: After you go to work C: After you wake up D: After you go to bed.<n><n>Example Answer: A: Before you get to work.<n><n>### Additional information<n>Exercise: Choose the correct preposition (infront at, on, behind by):<n>Input: Please explain your choice.<n><n>Exercises:<n>Choose the correct preposition between: at/on.<n>Examples: At 9:00, I get up.<n>At 9:00 P.M, I get up. on 9:00. <n><n>Input: please explain <n>Examples: At the movies, people watch movies before they go to bed.<n>Input: when should you do push-ups? I take a string argument <n>of a email address, and then return a boolean value. The value will<n>either be true, or false, or undefined.<n><n>The boolean return value is whether or not the user entered <n>in the email address on their sign up or user profile. It should also<n>only return a boolean value if the email address was actually <n>entered.<n><n>If the email address is a blank email address, it will return an <n>undefined string, ''. <n><n>My email check works like this: if a email address is typed in, <n>my function will take a look at the email address to see if it <n>has any email. It checks to see if the email is an email dot<n>the domain of the user you are signing up with. For example, if you <n>entered my email, it would check to see if "my_email_address" <n>was a valid domain, if so, it would return false. If the <n>"my_email_address", then it will return an undefiend string, <n>"". If the email is not typed in, it will do nothing, and will <n>not return and values.<n><n>Example of how it works. User enters my email in the email <n>address field:<n><n>  > my_check_email(["my_email_address"])     <n>  ["false"]<n><n>In this case, user typed in a email address that's not an email. This means it should return "true" or "false", but it also <n>should be a specific string that is returned. In this case, it returned a specific string: "false".<n><n>Exampe of a successful test. user entered "mailto:myemail@email.com" in the email field.<n><n>  > mycheckemail(["mailto:myemailaddress@email.com"]) <n>  ["true"]<n><n>In this example, I was

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Along what feature will you find a rosebush? Choices:  A: park B: in the ground C: hedgerow D: temperate climate E: botanical gardens<n><n>### Response:		<n>Demonstrate the task by creating a program in the language of choice that correctly answers the question.<n>* *Example*: In the given example, a rosebush is along a hedgerow.<n>* *Notes*: <n>  * All other answers are incorrect other than the one you provided.<n>  * Your program does not need to prompt the user for the input nor provide feedback. Your program should only read the input, evaluate the correct response and print that answer.<n>  * Remember! Test your program.<n>#### Notes:<n><*I*m*a*><n><n>### Solution:<n>#### Notes:<n>Input:Where do humans go in cities(input) to be in nature(choose)? A:movie theatre B:university C:park D:alaska E:country Output:Their go to be in nature to the park<n><*the*><n><n>## Source<n>HackerRank. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:If I have a reception with many people attending, where should I be sure to hold it? Choices:  A: grand casino B: large room C: restaurant D: country club E: lobby<n><n>### Response:		B: large room<n><n>### Explanation:<n>  Choice: A: grand casino      This is incorrect because Grand Casinos are not appropriate places to have a reception given its <n>  decorum.                   Choice: B: large room      This is correct given that a reception requires a large space to <n>  accommodate many people (large room). The choices C, D, and E are incorrect by themselves and also incorrect when paired <n>  with the first answer. Choice: C: university      This is incorrect since this is not a place to have a reception but rather a <n>  location to hold meetings.<n><n><n>### Input : Why might a customer use a credit card over cash when buying a product? Choices: <n><n>### Input A: Cards are easier to use than cash<n><n>### Input B: Cards are safer than cash<n><n>Both A and B are incorrect because credit cards and cash are equally easy to use, but cash often comes in larger denominations while credit cards are safer over cash because credit cards are traceable by the issuer.<n>  <n><n>**Expected Output:**<n><n>**C**:Cards are safer than <n><n>**Expected Reason:**<n><n>Cards are safer and easier to trace<n><n>### Input  : What does a car's mileage mean? Choices: 1.  kilometers traveled on a road.<n><n>### Input2: 2 miles<n><n>### Input3: 265 miles<n><n>Mileage is the number of miles a car travels. The second answer is incorrect given that each mile is equivalent to  4 096m (km). Mileage is the number expressed as a numerator of 4096 and can be multiplied or added by a different number of miles.The last answer is also incorrect since when multiplied by another number of miles, it results in a number of miles not kilometers.<n><n>### Expected Output:<n><n>   (364 m/mi)=7351 mi<n><n>### Reason:<n><n>Answer (364 m) is multiplied by 1 and we ended up with 364 m since each kilometer is 1000m. Then we multiply answer 1

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:You weren't suppose to touch the wild animals, they could what? Choices:  A: lie down B: run away C: bite D: keep alive E: feel pain<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices:  <n><n>A: lie down  <n>B: run away  <n>C: bite  <n>D: keep alive  <n>E: feel pain<n><n>```python<n>import spacy<n><n>nlp=spacy.load("en_core_web_sm")<n>doc = nlp("you weren't suppose (sic) to touch the wild animals")<n><n>#for the question we will have two options as answer for the input in the question section<n><n>for ans in ["lie down","run away","bite","keep alive","feel pain"]:<n><n>    ans_tokens=doc[ans].split()<n><n>    if ans_tokens=="lie down":<n>        ans_idxs=doc[ans_tokens].sents[0].text[:doc[ans_tokins].sents[0]].split()<n>    elif ans_tokens=="run away":<n>        ans_ids=doc[ans_torns].sents[0]+doc[ans_toktins].sents[0][-1]+doc[ans_tinks].sents[0];<n>    elif ans_troens=="bite":<n>        ans_tokens=word_index_by_word(ans_tokens)[1]<n>        ans_ids="{},{}".format(doc[ans_troens].sents[1].text,doc[ans_tokin].sents[1]); # we will put together the two sentences that are in the middle we did this because we want to use 2 senteces to answer but we dont want to use punctuation<n><n>    else:<n>        ans_ids=(doc[ans_toksins]).sents[0]; # if we find this is the only sentence in the doc that contains the token of course we will use it <n><n><n>### This section will be whats is asked in the question <n><n>print("Answer: ",ans_ids)<n>```<n><n>### Exercise:<n>Input:<n>Democrat<n>Answer:<n>Republican<n><n><n>### Solution:<n><n>```python<n>#this is the file that contain the data we want to use for our data<n><n>#first we need to get the corpus from the data<n>import spacy<n>nlp=spacies.load("en
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:As a human in a large northeastern city, where can you see animals? Choices:  A: zoo B: workplace C: sky D: new york city E: many places<n><n>### Response:		<n>While the only place I have encountered animals was at the zoo, I believe it is important for humans to have a place where they can see living things as they live free. The zoo is an artificial enclosure. Therefore the animals do not have the freedom to interact with one another and interact with their environment. The human’s only benefit from going to the zoo is to see wild animals; this interaction is a one-way exchange. Many of their behavioral traits have been extinguished in order to house them comfortably in this artificial manner. So, it is my belief that the park is the place where humans should interact with animals that have a normal, natural life. <n><n>### Instuction:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Input: If you lived in New York city, is there an advantage to living in a suburb or a city? Choices: Suburb: Better transportation, parks, recreation, noisy, etc.  City: noisy, limited parking & transportation.<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: If you lived in a place like New York City is it better to live in a crowded city or a crowded suburb? Choices: City: crowded, too expensive Suburb: crowded.<n><n>### Response<n>While there are arguments both for and against living in a city like New York, I believe there are many disadvantages. The crowds of the city can make you feel anxious and can be overwhelming. When I travel, I do not feel the need to keep looking behind me to see if a crowd of people is coming. I believe having space to live is not as important to people who are single or have families as far as financial needs. The lack of space seems to be a downside of living in a city, but I see people constantly making due with limited space. In addition, New York City would not be my place of choice to live because of how busy and noisy the city is. However, if it comes down to it, I know there are many advantages to living in a city. In conclusion, I believe it is better to live in a city like Newyork than in a suburb.<n><n>### Input and Display<n>If you lived in a dense city like New York, would you rather live in the center?  (Choice: yes or no)<n>[A screen shows a "No"

Choices:  A: ditch B: shop C: north america D: pet shops E: outdoors<n><n>### Response:		Too many people want exoctic snakes.  The supply of snakes in exotic environments is decreasing to fill the global demand. Exotic snakes in the wild are being captured and shipped to exotic snake breeders that are driving the increase in supply. Because there is already a glut in local trade, snake breeders are looking overseas for more wild and unwanted snakes. Snake species in their native environment are being decimated through both poaching and habitat loss. Demand for exotic snakes in North America has doubled in the last 15 years, but the number of snakes in that country has not. Wild exotic snakes are becoming the victims of illegal trade. The trend for North American pet snakes is exotic snakes.<n><n><n><n><n><n>### Instructions:<n><n><n>Please describe your response in words or phrases.<n>### Instruction Response:<n>This is an informative essay that provides a comprehensive and detailed response.<n>### Input:<n><n>### Input 1<n>Demand in North America is decreasing. Choose an answer A: launchpad B: circus C : plan C: aircraft carrier or D: wide open space E: space stations"<n>    # instructions = string.punctuation + "!?." + string.digits + string.punctuations<n><n>    # Extract all words in the instruction + [answer] from the sentence<n><n>    instructions = string.puncutations + "!?."+ string.digits +string.punctuation <n>    string = string.split (instruction,instructions) [0]<n><n>    # Loop through the list of possible answers<n>    for answer in answers:<n><n>        # If the answer is a match then print the user's response<n>        if answer == answer:<n>            print(f"Your answer is {answer}.")<n>            return<n><n>```<n>```python<n># Exercise 3. Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Where is a fox likely to be caught? Choices:  A: refrigerator B: fridge C: freezer D: oven E: bought at store<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n>#### **Demonstration:**<n>>I believe the answer to this question is choice (C), freezer, because if its kept in the freezer then it will not spoil as fast, it will also be fresh if it is not on the countertop.<n><n>Here is how you can implement this using [python](/howto/tutorial/python).<n><n>```python<n>answer = input()<n>for choice in choiceDict.keys():<n>    if answer == choice:<n>        print("Answer: " + choice)<n>        break<n>```<n><n>#### **Test:**<n>```python<n>answerA = input()<n>answerB = input()<n>answerC = input()<n>answerD = input()<n>answerE = input()<n>```<n><n>1. **answer** is, **answerA**<n><n>```python<n>if answer == answerA : <n>    print("Answer: "+"choicA")<n>    break    <n>```<n>2. **answer** is *choic**B**<n><n>```python**<n>if answer == answerB : <n>    print ("Answer: "+"choice B")<n>    break<n>```<n><n>3. **answer** is **choic**C**<n><n>```python <n>if answer == choiceC:<n>    print ("Answer "+"choice C")<n>    break<n><n>```<n>4. **answer** is  **choicE**<n><n>```python  <n>if answerE == choiceE:<n>    print("Answer "+"choice E")<n>    break <n><n>```<n><n>5. **answer** is choice **D**.<n><n>```python<n>print("Answer "+"choice "+"D")<n>break<n>```<n><n>### Comments and Questions:<n><n>

Choices:  A) The computer does not allow choices because you can't see a person's interests until they know what they want to be in a year<n>B) The computer doesn't work because its not advanced enough to know what I want or care about when I was 15<n>C) The computer is too personal for something this big<n>D) There is no point in asking, because things change every single year, I don't know what I want to be when I'm 16, so why 1 year earlier <n>E) The computer doesn'tknow how to learn about us<n><n>### Response 2: I believe there is a point in asking when you can't predict who you will be in the future. People always change their minds about these kinds of things, and they don't know they don't know it until they are in that situation. Choices:  A: mouth B: can C: human D: snake E: kentucky fried chicken<n><n>### Response:		<n>*What is a living thing that has a MOUTH (not a kentucky fried Chicken) and has a LIP?* <n><n>### ACCEPTED:<n>```<n>*The MOUTH is the entire thing that leads to the LIP. <n>A living thing with a MOUTH and LIP is a HUMAN.*<n>```<n><n>### Example with the prompt: "Where do humans go in cities _to be in nature?_ Choices: A: movie theatre B : university C: park D : alaska E: country" <n><n>The complete response is:  *What is a living thing _that has a MOUTH AND HAS A LIP_ and can go to a _city_?*

Choices:  A: too much B: act dead C: die D: rush E: explode<n><n>### Response:		C: Die or rush depending on the altitude of the tree<n><n>### Question: Which of the following statements is true?<n><n>### Demstration:<n><n>Input: 1: The number of minutes in a month are 31<n><n>Input: 2: The number of seconds in a month are 24<n><n>Input: 3: The number of minutes per day are 60<n><n># Input: Which of the above statements is false?<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write the following sentences. Make sure you follow the pattern shown.<n><n>### Example 1<n>```The first sentence of this group does not match the other sentences in this group. This is a group of sentences. The sentences in this group are the same except the last one!```<n><n>### Example response 1:<n>```The first sentence is not the same as the other sentences in this sentence. The sentences in this sentence are the same except the one I'm currently writing!``<n><n>### Example Response 2:<n>```The first statement is not the same as other statements in this group of sentences. All the sentences in this sequence are the same except the sentence I'm creating right now! ```<n><n>### Example Responses<n>```The first sentence in this sentence is not like the other sentences in this sequence. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:There was a saucepan used only for marinara, where was it kept? Choices:  A: georgia B: the south pole C: kitchen cupboard D: italian restaurant E: boil eggs<n><n>### Response:		C: kitchen cupboard<n>### Solution:Answer: D: italian restaurant<n><n>### Explanation:Input: There was a saucepan only used for marinara, <n>where was it kept? Chooses A-D as they have something to do with italian cuisine, however there is no such thing as marinara only used for that. The correct answer would be E as you can't cook a sauce when it's empty. An AI would have to have knowledge about different cuisines like italian cuisine that a sauces that are only cooked in italian cuisine have that name and can not be cooked by other means. Also, the AI would have to know that a sauce when it is not being cooked is not useful and it must be kept in the cupboard.<n>Human beings tend to not be very formal sometimes when describing problems, an AI should know how to decode ambiguous questions for the best possible answer.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Someone who doesn't care about about someone else and wishes them to fail has what feeling towards them? Choices:  A: unfeeling B: negligence C: antipathy D: indifferent E: rapport<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n><n><n><n>### Bonus: What is a good way to store a value after the data dies?<n><n>### Solution:<n><n><n>```python<n>"""This example script demonstrates an easy way to store values <n>of any length and convert it into a unicode str.<n>Notes:<n>* There is currently no API built into Python that can easily be used to store variable length values as a unicode string.<n>* The reason is simple, most API use Unicode. So it would be easier to allow users to define their own ways of storing Unicode values.<n>* Using pickle is easy but requires some conversion when trying to work with the stored value later on."""<n>class store_unicode(object):<n>    def __init__(self, var:str):<n>        self.val = var<n>        <n>    def __str__(self):<n>        if type(self.val) == str:<n>            return self.val<n>        else:<n>            return u"Error: value not string"<n># Example<n>var1 = 'hello, my name is john'<n>var2 = 'this is a sentence'<n><n># Store<n>myval = store_unicode(var1)<n>print(myval.val) # hello, my name is jon<n>myval = store(var2)<n>print(myvla.val) # this is a sentence<n># Read<n>myval = store("Hello, my name is jj")<n>print(myval) # hello,my name is jj<n>myval = store.myval("Hello, this is a sentence")<n>print(myv) # Hello,this is a sentence<n>```

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What did the business require of everyone walking into their store? Choices:  A: wear shoes B: learn C: hope for peace D: have a great day. E: do well<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n><n>### Input<n>What is the purpose of the `public static` keyword when declaring a method? Choices: A: to make the function public. B: to prevent the method from being accessed from within a constructor. C: to make the function private. D: to make the method accessible only inside the function.<n><n>### Output<n><n>C. It restricts access to the method<n><n>### What else?<n>The `final` keyword also makes the method accessible only inside a function.<n>A _function_ is a series of instructions that can be called on a variable.<n><n>### Why?<n>An object is something that can be created, stored in memory, and access it whenever you wish. The object is stored in memory as a series of fields.<n>A field is a variable that is part of an object.<n><n>### What does this mean?<n>To run the function, you first have to create an object (the store) and then use the object to call the function on the object.<n><n><n>## Description<n><n>An expression such as a number, a string, an object, or the output of another expression, is called a value.<n>A _reference_ is a way to refer to a value. A reference can be: an object, a field of an object, or a method of an object.<n>If you want to refer to a value, use a _reference_.<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:The college kids weren't known for their apartment decor choices, they used a folding chair inside their what? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:A yard is made up of what? Choices:  A: city B: michigan C: three feet D: subdivision E: three arm span<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>``` python<n>import requests<n>from bs4 import BeautifulSoup as bs<n><n>URL = "http://google.com/url?as_q=where+do+people+go+in+cities+to+relax.+"<n><n>headers = {<n>    "referer":URL,<n>    "user-agent": "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/89.0.4389.90 Safari/537.46 Edg/89.0"<n>}<n><n>r = requests.get("https://evolution.org/languages")<n><n>soup=bs(r.content,"html.parser")<n>title=soup.find('title')<n><n>print(title.strip())<n>```<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:A shark swam in the background aquarium as the card players sat emotionless, what were they playing? Choices:  A: sea world B: court room C: shallow waters D: poker game E: card shark<n><n>### Response:		A: sea world<n><n>### Input- Answer if the following condition does or does not include the input.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Input: What is the main element in a musical.<n>Explanation: Yes the answer is a (song or melody). <n><n><n>### Instructions: <n>There are two ways to do this section. They are described in two different ways. There are three parts.<n><n>### Way #1<n><n>### Part 1:<n>### Demo:<n>Write a program that takes an expression of the form A + B and outputs the total. The example given for the first part is 5 + 4.<n><n>### Part2:<n>Write a program for the second part using the same format as the first part. The example given for this part is 5 + (1 + 8 * 2). <n><n>### Part3:<n>Write a program to do both parts as the user can enter an expression with an arithmetic operation in any of the three spaces. <n><n>### Instction: <n>Use the same format as in the second part below. The only difference is, the total does not always start from the left.<n><n>### Demo: Answers<n>```javascript<n>var  arr = [];<n>for(var i = 0; i < arr.length; i++) {<n>    var  num = arr[i];<n>    if(i == 0)<n>        sum = num<n>    else<n>        sum = sum + num;<n>}<n>```<n>### Instrucion:<n><n>### Demo<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What kind of place could have thousands of statue? Choices:  A: church B: theatre C: large city D: water fountain E: central park<n><n>### Response:		E:Central park<n><n>### The Code<n>```python<n>def answer(question):<n>    choices = ["A:" + str(question[0]),"B:" + str(question<n>[1]),"C:" + str(question),"D:" + str(question [3]),"E:" + str(question <n>[4])]<n>    return random.choice('ABCDE')<n>```

Choices:  A: concert B: home C: airport D: college E: university<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input Choices:<n>- A<n>- B<n>- C<n><n>### Output Answer<n><n>### Solution<n>```python<n>"""<n>Demonstration:<n>"""<n><n>if True:<n><n>    a = ("movie theatre")<n>    b = ("university")<n>    c = ("park")<n>    d = ("alaska")<n>    e = ("country")<n><n><n>else:<n>    <n>    a = ("park")<n><n>if a ==("movie theatre"):<n>    print ("true")<n><n>elif a==("university") :<n>    print ("is true")<n><n>elif a ==( "park"):<n>    print("Answear")<n><n>else:<n>    a = b<n>    if a ==("university"):<n>        print ("True")<n><n>    else:<n>        print("is not true")<n>```<n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:A beaver builds structures to block what sort of feature? Choices:  A: books B: zoo C: body of water D: wooded area E: animals<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Input:Where do humans go in cities <n>to be in nature?<n><n>Answer: <n><n>### C:\scripts\0000.py<n><n>```python<n>#!/bin/python3<n>while True:<n>    print("Answer choices")<n>    print("1. A: movie theatre")<n>    print("2. B: university")<n>    print("3. C: park")<n>    print("4. D: alaska")<n>    print("5. E: country")<n>    print("\nPlease select an answer choice")<n>    choice = input()<n>    if choice == '1':<n>        print("Please select an answer choice that is not A: movie theatre")         # This will run in a separate process via fork<n>    elif choice =='2':<n>        print("1. A movie theatre")<n>    elif choice == 'Q':<n>        break<n>    else:<n>        print("Please enter a valid answer choice")<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What body of water is typically shallow water? Choices:  A: lake B: aquariums C: swimming pool D: pond E: childrens pools<n><n>### Response:		D: pond (for lake, aquarium, and swimmingpool are all bodies of water, they use the word pool instead, and D is the only choice that specifies water is shallow.<n><n>### Input : What body of water is typically deep water? Choices: A: ocean B: lake C: canal D: pool E: aquarium<n><n>### Response : D: pool (for lake, aquariums, and swimming pool are all bodies of water. lake uses the word water, swimming pool uses the word pool and pool has no depth specification. pool is the only choice which uses the word deep and doesnt specify any kind of water.<n><n>### Answer: swimming pool (for ocean is a whole different kind of body of water and is not defined as shallow or deep.)<n><n>### Input A: In general, what color is the sky during sunrise? Choices: A :black B: white C: green D: clear E: yellow<n><n>### Response D:clear (for A, B, C, clear and white are both choices that do not describe color. for D, if no specification is added, it is the default answer because it leaves a good description of the sky as being clear.<n><n>

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:The person turned the oven on and put a pizza in, what happened one hour later? Choices:  A: smell smoke B: catch cold C: burnt D: look angry E: bank savings<n><n>### Response:		<n>> The answer is C: burnt.<n>><n>> The person turned the oven to a high temperature, then put the pizza in the oven, at this moment the temperature in the oven is very high but the pizza does not cook immediately, it takes time. After the oven has reached a certain temperature, the pizza will smoke, so that's why the person smelled smoke.<n><n>### Question: You put your hand on the floor, what happened?<n><n>Response:<n>> Your hand will put down force on the floor, then they both will get the same down force, and this state will last for a certain period of time until there's no force, this is how I can say that your hand has the same force as the floor. But if there is friction on the floor, the force will decrease little by little until it become zero.<n><n>### Input question: What is the answer of the question: "What is the name of the movie"?. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What could happen to a paper if you leave it outside even if it does not move? Choices:  A: one material often recycled B: ripped C: saturated with water D: one dimensional E: crumpled<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices: C: saturated B: ripped<n>### Instruction<n>Write a program that answers the questions.<n><n>Use any language that you want.<n><n>The input is a list of choices and their corresponding answers. The answer to any choice is always one of the choices.  <n><n>### Demostration:<n>The solution for the first exercise is:<n>```python<n># Answer = "C: park"<n>inputChoices = ["A: movie theatre", "B: university", "C: park", "D: alaska", "E: country"]<n>answerIndex = lambda inputChoices: inputChoices.index(inputChoices[0])<n># Return the index of the answer in the list of choices<n>answerIndex['C: park']<n><n># Note: The inputChoices.index() lambda is called a lambda function<n>```<n><n>### Response<n>I was not able to come up with an actual solution to the second exercise.<n><n>### Exercise<n>The same input and function definitions are used for every exercise so you're not allowed to change them. Here is an example of expected output:<n><n>### Response Examples:<n>```python<n>inputChoices = ['C: park', 'A: movie theatre', 'C: park', 'B: university', 'D: alaska', 'A: movie theater']<n># Example #1<n>answer = lambda inputChoices, choices: inputChoices[inputChoices.index(choices)]<n># Example #2<n>answer2 = lambda inputChoices = ["A", "B", "A"], choices: inputChoices.pop(inputChoices.index([choice for choice in choices if choice]) % len(inputChoices))<n>```<n>

Satisfied B. Alive C. Relaxed D. Happier E. Rich<n>```<n>### Instructions<n>How does happiness feel:<n><n>Choices:A: Satisfied B: Alive C: Relaxed D:Happier E: Rich<n><n>```<n># This is me testing this method<n># I have two responses<n><n>```<n># Testing this response<n># This is my first response<n><n>```<n># and this is second response<n>```<n><n>```<n>### Testing this method<n><n>### Instructions<n>What is your name.<n>Choices: A : Mark B: D:E<n><n>```<n>## Testing the method I wrote.<n>```<n>```<n># What is your name.<n># Mark<n>```<n>```<n><n>```

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:He wore the wrong shoes while walking all day, now he has what on his heels and toes? Choices:  A: exercise B: moving forward C: feet D: blisters E: locomotion<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>def run(word):<n>    input = input(word)<n>    if input in ["e", "p"]:<n>        return "e"<n>    elif input == "t":<n>        return "t" <n>    elif input == "+":<n>        return "p"<n>    else:<n>        return "n"<n>      ```<n><n>```python<n><n>```<n><n>### Reasoning:<n>The first letter of the list must be run and should be equal to input "e". That letter should be lower in the list, so it should be last. For the second letter, the input must be "p", which is the third element on the list.<n>### Outcome<n>The program will print "e" when the word input is "e" and "p" when the word input<n>      is "p".

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Having a car in the city seemed to be more trouble than it was worth, the man still had to walk to and from the what after commuting? Choices:  A: driveway B: the event C: scrap heap D: parking garage E: repair shop<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: driveway<n><n>### Solution<n>```python<n>while True:<n>	inputted = str(input("Write a program that completes the request\n"))<n>	result = inputted.lower()<n>	if result.startswith("what"):<n>		answers = ["movie theatre", "university", "park", "Alaska", "Country"]<n>		return options[result.split(' ')[2]]<n>```<n>## A Simple Question for a Mathematician<n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a program that asks two questions of a mathematician. <n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input: Given that Pi = 3.14, what is it rounded to 2 Digits? Choices: A: 3.1(Enter) B: 3.6(Enter)<n><n>Answer: C: 3.2(Enter)<n><n>Input: Given PI = 3.12(Enter),  What is it rounded to 3 Digits? Choices A: 312.0(Enter) B: _____(Enter)*<n><n>Response: C: 312<n><n>### Solution(using str)<n><n>```python<n># while True:<n>while True: <n>	while True:<n>		input = str(input("Given that Pi = " + str((input + input) / 2)))<n>		if not(input == input.split(".")[0]): break<n>		input.append(",")<n>		if input.find(".")!=-1:<n>			input = input.replace(",","")<n>	if(input.split(".")[1] == "00"):<n>		return input.split(".")<n># if not(input == input.split(".")[0])  :<n>if (len(input) > 3):<n>	break<n>input = input.split(".") <n>if (input[0] == input.split(".",1)+"") :<n>	return input.split(",")[1]<n>```<n>### Solution(Using tuples)<n>```python<n><n>```<n><n><n>### A Simple Calculator<n>### Demonstation<n>```<n><n>`  Input:  "Given that 1 + 1 + 1 =  (Enter

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Why might a person go to get counseling? Choices:  A: to be heard B: receive gifts C: understand themselves D: good things in life E: acknowledgment<n><n>### Response:		Why might a person go to seek counseling? (A: to be heard, B:gain understanding about themselves, C: to get rid of past issues, D: to get an acknowledgement(s)). Counseling is a service that helps people by assisting with understanding themselves and their life experiences in a way that helps to make positive changes. Some of the things you might be wondering why one may seek to go and get counseling is to seek out understanding concerning an issue that is effecting their life, such as mental health concerns, relationship with a person or even a particular topic. One reason for this is: " to have an unbiased and objective view of your perspective" (Counseling.com website.). "It is important to understand the person with whom you are talking. If you understand the person, you are more likely to know how to treat him or her" (AskDrKim website.).<n><n>### Instructions:Why might a person be in a place of need?  Choices:  A) To receive medical needs B) Counseling C) Employment needs D) Other<n><n>### Response answer: There are many reasons a person could be in need. Some people in need go into programs with the intent to receive different employment opportunities or counseling. Some people need assistance, not just counseling, to be able to get on their feet and take on new challenges that a job can offer.  Some needs are more in need in other aspects, but counseling is a great help when it comes to many areas in life, not just the aspects of employment. Some of these help people gain a better understanding of themselves and their life experiences to make better decisions that can help them to create a better quality of life for themselves.<n><n>### Question answer: The question above asked, “Why might a person want to go to a doctor for medical needs?” I think counseling services is a similar profession. Some of the services that mental health can offer a person are to help them understand themselves better to help them work through issues and life experiences that have been difficult to comprehend. Not only is mental health services a place for people to get to understand themselves better, but it is also a place for people to be supported in the process of life changes. <n><n>### Instutions: How much do you know mental health needs?<n><n>### Resources used to answer

Choices: A: bicycles B: cats C: cars D: coins E: dogs F: fire<n><n>### <n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:The old barn was beyond repair, they had to destroy it before they could what a new one? Choices:  A: make B: raise C: entice D: build E: fix<n><n>### Response:		<n>C: raised<n><n>Input:When you want a drink of water, you should reach to what place? Choices: <n>A: right side <n>B: the shelf <n>C: the floor <n>D: the fridge <n>E: to the table<n><n>### Response <n>B: the Shelf<n><n>### Instructions: <n>Write a program in C# that allows the user to input choices from a list of choices. Include in the program the following methods:<n><n>a) Prompt the user to input a choice<n><n>b) Display a message for each choice in the following format: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, etc. <n><n>c) After choosing a choice and completing a program, the user will get the following messages:<n>    d) the user has a choice<n>    e) the user has made a mistake<n>    f) the user did the right question<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>\begin{code}<n>  using System;<n>  using System.Collections.Generic;<n>  using System;using System.Linq;<n><n>Class Program<n>{<n>    public void Menu()<n>    {<n>        Console.WriteLine("1, 2,3,4...");<n>    }<n>    public void InputChoice(String question)<n>    {<n>        string chosen =<n>        Int.Parse(Console.ReadLine());<n>        var options = Enum.GetValues(typeof(Choice));<n>        foreach (Choice item in options)<n>        {<n>            if(item.ToString() == chosen)<n>            {<n>                Console.WriteLine("Choice :" + item.ToString());<n>                Console.WriteLine(int.Parse(Console.WriteLine("Type the message that contains 1, 2 3..... ")<n>                chosen);<n>                Console.WriteLine (int.Parse(Console<n>               .WriteLine("You made some choices")))<n>                Console.WriteLine((int.Parse(Console    <n>               .WriteLine("The right choice is : 1")) ));<n>            }<n>        }<n>    }<n>}<n>\end{code}<n><n>### Output:<n><n>1, 2, A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K, L, M, N, O, P, Q<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Why is waiting for the doctor difficult for people who need to do work? Choices:  A: having appointements B: being late C: have time to think D: time consuming E: impatience<n><n>### Response:		<n>In many countries doctors don't charge as much for appointments with them. People who don't have their own doctor often have to make appointments to see one and waiting for an appointment can cost money. A lot of people can only see their doctor during their lunch break and it doesn't really take the doctor long to see them. They will wait if they need to which is often true for people who don't even have a doctor. For reasons like this people are often late for an appointment with their doctor and they have to reschedule which can be very inconvenient if it's been set in your head as a day to do important work.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:James was looking for a place to buy bitcoins.  He searched and found a large menu of what? Choices:  A: advertisement B: news C: bar D: cafe E: internet sites<n><n>### Response:		E: internet sites<n><n><n>```python<n>#!/usr/bin/python3<n><n>import sys<n><n>if __name__ == '__main__':<n>    print('Input:' + sys.argv[1])<n>    response = ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D', 'E']<n>    answer = '%s' % response [ int(sys.argv[1]) ]<n><n>    print('\nDemonstration:')<n>    print('Input:', sys.argv[1] +'Choices:')<n>    for index in range(0, len(response)):<n>        print('\t', response[index], index + 1)<n><n>    print('\t','Answer:')<n>    print('\t', answer)<n><n>    print('Response:')<n>    print(sys.argv[2])<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: erections B: entertainment C: boredom D: get fat E: sadness<n><n>### Response:		C: boredom<n>### Instruction<n>Answer the multiple choice question.<n>### Demonstraion<n>Answer: boredom<n><n># -*- coding challenge -*-<n><n>## Instructions<n>I'm watching tv, What do I expect to get out of this?<n><n>### Demosion<n>I'm watching TV because there is nothing else you can do. What I expect to get is boredom. <n><n>### Instructions<n>Answer the following multiple-choice question<n><n>### Demostration<n>This is the answer, A: Boredom<n><n>#-*- coding challenge - *-<n><n>```ruby<n>class User<n>  def initialize(name, email, password, age)<n>    @Age = age<n>    @Email = email<n>    @Name = name<n>    @Password = password<n>  end <n>end<n>```<n><n>## Instrucions<n>create a constructor so that name, email.age, and password are included<n><n>## Demonstration<n><n>```ruby<n>user = User.new("John","john@gmail.com",10,"s3cr3tw0rk1")<n>```<n><n>## Istrucctions<n>Write a method called has_same_name? that will compare two names and find out if they are<n>        the same<n><n>## Example<n>```ruby<n>jake = User.new("Jake", "jake@gmail.com", 20, "s3cr3twor1k2")<n><n>if jake.has_same_name?("Jake")<n>#DoSomething<n>end<n>```<n>## Demo<n>In this demo if I call has_same_name method with user object and another name, it will return the result as true or false.<n><n># -* coding challenge -*<n><n>```Ruby<n>class User<n>   def initialize(name, age, email, password)<n>     @Age = age<n>     @Email = email<n>     @Name = name<n>     @Password = password<n>   end <n>end<n><n>user = User.instance()<n><n>method()<n><n>if method<n>  print "Good"<n>else<n>  print "Bad"<n>end<n>```<n>Output of this console should be "Bad".<n># -* codingchallenge - *<n><n>## Instrucitons<n>Write

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:He found the blowfish off the coast of the Carolina's, it was where? Choices:  A: rock band B: sea of japan C: sushi restaurant D: fish market E: atlantic ocean<n><n>### Response:		Where did he find the blow fish? <n><n>### Explanation:<n>There is a 50% chance of choosing each item. Choices have equal probability and it is easy to calculate the probability of choosing one item over the other.<n>The two choices that contain items, C and D, have a probability of 1/8 of not choosing those items.<n><n><n><n>

This was because the cat knocked over a table that contained George's present which caused George to ruin the surprise and the cat to leave.<n><n>### How:<n>This is to show that the bot is able to read input and formulate an appropriate response to follow the rules required by the prompt.

Choices:  A: turn away B: let down C: have to sleep D: run E: row boat<n><n>### Response:		<n>```javascript<n>function getParsedInput (text) {<n>  return JSON.parse(text)<n>};<n><n>var choices = getParsedInput('Choices:  A:movie theatre B:university C:park D:alaska E:country');<n>var answer = getParsedIntput('Input: What type of water transportation human powered?').split(' ')[0];<n>var response = '';<n>for (var property in choices){<n>  if(choice[property] === answer){<n>    response = `${property}`<n>  }<n>}<n>console.log(response.toUpperCase())<n>```

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What do customers do in a store? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:The keys were black and white, what were they attached to? Choices:  A: front pocket B: cabinet C: purse D: chain E: piano<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```python<n>def AnswerT(cities, humans, cities):<n><n>  if cities == humans:<n>      return "yes"<n>  else:<n>       return "no"<n>```<n><n>### Explanation:<n>If cities = humans, return "yes". if cities!=humans, return "no".<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What would humans do when their legs are tired? Choices:  A: sit down B: make mistakes C: have sex D: reproduce E: excrete<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>**Input**: What would humans do when their leg are tired? Choices A: sit down B.make mistakes C: have sex   D: reproduce E:excrete<n><n>**Response**:Humans are animals who require food to exist. They eat animals. To do this they must hunt and fight other animals or search for food. Humans do not have fur and so do not need to hibernate. Instead, because they are mammals, humans take care of their young. Human babies require their mothers to feed them so adults must work to earn money to do this. This may include hunting and fighting. Humans do this often, so hunters must learn how to do it well, and so men may practice until they are experts in order to have the highest chance of killing animals. They fight with many different weapons, including arrows, rocks and spears. They also sometimes fight using weapons they have built, like long, spiked sticks with sharp points. Humans also fight many battles to defend their homes and countries. Hunting and fighting requires strength, and a strong body is a good one to have. Some humans make mistakes or make poor choices when they are tired. When this happens, they may lose fights and their children may die. They may also lose access to their homes and land, when this happens they go to other areas and hunt and fight.<n><n>**Input**:"Humans live in buildings" Answer A: Building B: houses C: homes D: flat E: houses"<n><n>**Response**"Humans live in houses"<n><n>**Input**"When humans enter a building what happens?"<n><n>**Response**<n>"When they get home they go to sleep and then they wake up. When humans eat they use their mouth. But sometimes they cut things to eat them with"<n><n>**Input"When they need to find other humans they..."?"<n><n>**Response"they get in their cars and drive"<n><n>**Input:What should humans do when they get home?<n><n>**Response"They get in their car and go to the barn"<n><n>**Input :"They usually get in their car to go home"<n><n>**Response"when humans finish fighting their food, animals and trees get in their cars and  go home"<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Where are small grapes used? Choices:  A: picnic basket B: wine press C: juice D: fruit cocktail E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		E: kitchen<n><n># - A,B,C,D for choice A,B,C and D<n>### Test Code:<n>	```python<n>	# A,B,C answer<n>	import sys<n>	<n>	answers = ('Movie theatre', 'Alaska', 'University', 'Outback')<n>	<n>	def test1(inputString, answerArray):<n>	        correct, wrong = False, False<n>	        print('Input: %s'%inputString)<n>	        print('Your answer: %s'%answerArray)<n>	        print()<n>	        for answer in answerArray:<n>	            if inputString == answer:<n>	                correct=True<n>	                break<n>	        if correct == True:<n>	            print('Correct!')<n>	        else:<n>	            print()<n>	            print('Please note down your answer and send it to me.')<n>	<n>	inputString = input('Please enter a string which you expect your robot will choose.')<n>	answerArray = input('Please enter other 4 answers you expect your robot will not choose.')<n>	if (inputString in answers) and (not any(answer in answerArray for answer in answers[inputString].split())):<n>	    print('Correct! The robot will choose %s.'%answerString)<n>	else:<n>	    print()<n>	    print('Please note down something that will help you pass this interview.')<n>	inputString = 'Please enter a string which your robot will choose'<n>	choice = input(inputString)<n>	```<n><n><n>## Instruction:<n><n>## Demonstration:  <n><n>Write an expression that multiplies a number by 6 (or the letter "X" if you like).<n><n>### Task:<n>Write the following expressions in your lab notebook.<n><n>1. 2 * 6<n>2. 6 + 1<n><n>### Response :<n>2 * 6 = 12  <n>6 + 1 = 7<n><n>### Test Code<n>```python<n>ans_string = ''<n>for i in range(10):<n>    inputString = input('Enter a number.')<n>    ans_string += inputString * 6<n>```<n><n>## Instruction :<n>Ask "what is 25 times 10

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:In war, your primary method is combat, but your goal is to do what? Choices:  A: conquer opponent B: fight enemy C: join army D: kill E: terrible<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input and Input types<n>### Input: Your goal is to take your friend on a nice date. You decided to invite them to dinner and a movie. Where do you take your friend for dinner? Choices: A: movie theatre B. restaurant C: house D: country E: restaurant<n><n>### Response to question below:<n><n>If there are two responses that are possible, both answers will have a colon (:) attached between the response and answer.<n>For example if answer was to go to a restaurant, that response will end with :restaurant.<n><n>### Input to question below:<n>Your friend just got out of the military and has been doing a lot of hiking but is unsure what to wear on a special occasion. What does the wardrobe include? Choices: 1. A. boots 2. B. leggings 3. C. tennis shoes 3. D. pants 4. E. tank top<n><n>### Response<n>If there is no more than one response that is possible, the answer will match the response exactly.<n>The response and answer will be separated by two periods. (.)<n>For example if response to question was clothing include pants, the answer would be pants without the colon (:)
