Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:The drug kingpin told his man to run errands, this was code to go to all the dealers to do what they had? Choices:  A: park B: make time for C: receive instructions D: take money E: leave work<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>answers = ["A", "B", "C", "D", "E"]<n># Choose the answer that best matches the description to the best of your ability.<n>while(len(answers)>0):<n>    print("\n")<n>    answer_choice = input("Please select choice: ")<n>    if(answer_choice == "q"):<n>        break<n>    answer = [choice for choice,choice_label in zip(answers,['a','b','c','d','e']) if (choice==answers[i])]<n>    answers.pop(answer)<n>    if (answer_choice == "a"):<n>        print("Choice is correct!")<n>        break<n>    else:<n>        print("Incorrect! Please enter again to continue:")<n>        continue

Choices:  A: costly B: captive C: contained D: paying E: caught<n><n>### Response:		<n>C: captive<n>### Explanation:A microtransaction is a small amount paid for a virtual good that the software or website allows the user to purchase for free.<n>### Explanations:1: When parents use the game's microtransactions, their child's phone stays close by during play. 2: A free game that allows the player to pay for extras. 3: When a large payment is made to a company so that they get a percentage of what the customer pays in the future. 4: When a large payment to a company is made to get some sort of payment in the future. 5: When someone can't get what they want.<n>### Instruction<n>How do I use a list with a nested loop <n><n>### Demo:<n>Input:What is the total of squares 1 through (a) and squares (b) through 12.<n><n>Answer: E = b(b+1)/2 (a+1)(a+2)/2<n>### Response<n>I believe your response should be C.<n><n>### Explanatipn: You could change your question to <n>What is the total of x*y<n>And solve it with your method.<n><n>### Challenge<n>What is a better method to get the solution A or B. Write a Python function named `count_letters`, which accepts a string as an input in lower case letters. This function should return an array with one item, the number of lower case letters in the string. An example of this function should be `count_letters('pig') = [2]`.<n><n>### Demostration:<n>input:count_letters("dog") output: [1]<n><n>import string<n>pig = "wow I found so many letters in dog in lower case!!"<n>pig = pig.lower()<n>f = string.ascii_lowercase<n>print(f.count(pig))<n><n><n>2. Write a Python function to verify if the first and the last names match in the dictionary as input. If they match, return True, else return False. For example the input of dictionary should be `{'John' : 'Doe', 'Jane' :'smith'}`. If the first and the last name match, the expected output should be `True`. Here are some example outputs for this function:<n>     - input `{'John' :'Doe', 'Anne' :'Doe'}`. Output: False<n>     - input ` {'John' :'Do', 'Anne'':'sm}'. Output: False`<n>     - input ` { 'John' :'Doer', 'Anne' :'smith' }`. Output: True<n>     - input ` '{John' :'Doing', 'Anne':'smith'} `. Output : False<n>1. As an example, if we have a dictionary with 4 key items with value as "A", "B", "C" and "D" and the count as "5", "10", "20", "30" and "100" respectively. The expected output should be `['D','30', '100']`.<n><n>### Demosration:<n><n>import random<n><n>random_var = {}<n><n>random_var['first_name'] = "John"<n>random_var['last_name'] = "Doe"<n>random_var["age"] = 26<n>

These dictionaries all include the capital letters a-z, but are otherwise empty. The program will then ask for a list of words, words will be created with dictionaries in a way that's not obvious to the human who enters the word<n><n>## Input: a-z<n>## Output (empty dictionary): {'a': set(), 'b': set(), 'c': set(), 'd': set(), 'e': set(), 'f': set(), 'g': set(), 'h': set(), 'i': set(), 'j': set(), 'k': set(), 'l': set(),'m': set(), 'n': set(), 'o': set(), 'p': set(), 'q': set(), 'r': set(),'s': set(), 't': set(), 'u': set(), 'v': set(), 'w': set(), 'x': set(), 'y': set(), 'z': set()}<n><n>### the program will create a dictionary with the input then create a set and add all the numbers into that set then add the dictionary to that set and add the word that was entered by the user to that set<n><n>## Input: "fox"<n>## Output: "fox"<n><n>### the dictionary created will be a capital F then a capital X<n>### then an empty set<n><n>## Task:<n>Create a dictionary that includes only the most commonly used verbs in English. Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:The old man was retired and liked the simple things, he would do crossword puzzle every morning simply just to do what? Choices:  A: you're bored B: pass time C: relax D: mentally challenged E: win<n><n>### Response:		A: you're bored<n><n>### Justify your answer.<n>The old man liked the simple things and liked cross words because it was simple but it challenged his mental growth<n><n>**Reference**: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5-9H-bjf4aQ<n><n>The task is a multiple choice question. We are required to answer the question by choosing the correct option.<n><n>### What is an Instruction?<n><n>**Ref:** https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Command<n><n><n>**Ref:1:** https://www.cs.odu.edu/~piper/cs332/notes/language_1.html<n><n><n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What would an adult man do to get ready for work? Choices:  A: dress herself B: shower C: dress himself D: drink beer E: drive train<n><n>### Response:		<n>> The man would dress himself.<n><n>### Input :What would an adult man dress? Choices: <n><n>1. A: a uniform <n><n>2. B: slacks<n><n>3. C: a tie<n><n>4. D:  socks<n><n>5. E: a tuxedo<n><n>Answer:<n>1. A: B<n><n>2. B. A<n><n>3. B. C<n><n>4. D. B<n><n>5. A. B<n><n>> An adult man would dress in slacks.<n><n>### Task:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: What's the best way to get a job? Choices: 1:  dress formally  2:  take bus  3: have college degree  4:  take subway  5: apply for jobs on twitter  6:  take ride sharing service  <n>Answer: 4: The best way to get a a job is to take the subway<n><n>### Input and Instruction:<n>> Write an app that can understand a question as input, decide on the response, and return it as output.<n><n>### Response for the above question:<n>To take a quick drive to your destination it is best to take a subway service rather than a bus.<n><n>### Notes:<n>1. The input format is simple to understand and the answer format is simple and short.<n>2. The goal is to write code with the least possible number of lines, so try to stick within the 20-30 char limit.<n>3. If it is difficult to describe an output for a given question (or if it generates a wide range of answers depending on the response), include multiple questions that provide multiple answers.<n>4. This task is different from a unit test because the problem is not "if the code works" but "if the output is correct"<n>5. You cannot return an exception or error.  If you need to, return a response that says the question could not be answered.  There are limits when writing code, like time constraints.<n>6. This problem is a natural language problem and the app will take a specific input and make a response and the input and response will  be in human comprehensible format, that is the output.<n>7. You cannot just return a specific answer. The app has to be able to understand that the answer is

Here is my comment: [Comment: ] <n>  * [ ] I would like to see revision, and [ ] I have no further comments<n><n>--------------------------------------------------------<n>---<n>##### Instructor name:

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What building has a ot of glue bottles? Choices:  A: art room B: police station C: classroom D: desk drawer E: school<n><n>### Response:		Desk drawer<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Certain input is provided. After the input is read, the program continues until the prompt is responded to. The program will continue looping until the input prompt is met.<n><n>### Input examples:<n>What building has a ot fo glue bottles?<n><n>### Code Example:<n>```<n>import random<n><n>answer = "A"<n><n>while True:<n>  input = input().lower()<n>  if input == "a":<n>    response = answer<n>    print(response)<n>    break<n>  else:<n>    answer = input<n> <n><n>```<n>

Choices: A: at home B: in refrigerator C: at office<n><n>### Response <n><n>```python<n>if (x=="home"):<n>    print("C")<n>if (x=="refrigerator"):<n>    print ("B")<n>if (x == "office"):<n>    print (D)<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:The priest pushed for more orthodox behavior, what kind of behavior was he trying to stop? Choices: B: remove one option C: choose the most popular one or multiple combination of the options  D: add more choices<n><n>### Output:<n>"Add more choices"<n>```javascript<n>function choose(){<n>    a=prompt("What would you do with the dictionary?","A. Choose the most popular option");<n>    if(a=="A. Choose the popular option"){<n>        console.log("Add more choices");<n>    }else if(a=="B. Take the dictionary to the library"){<n>        console.lo g("Remove on option");<n>        }else if(a==="C. Take the dictionary to study area"){<n>        console .lo g("Choose the most popular one or combination of the options");<n>       }else if(a===="D. Take the dictionary to school"){<n>        console  .lo g("Take the dictionary to school");<n>    }<n>}<n>choose();<n>```<n><n>### Instiction:You need to write a function that takes a two numbers and returns their sum.<n>### Demonstion:<n>```javascript<n>function addTwoNumbers(num1,num2){<n><n>    return(num1+num2)<n>}<n><n>// addTwoNumbers(4,8)<n>5<n>```<n><n>## Task:You need to write the code for the output<n>### You have the following two-character strings and you need to return the output as the letter corresponding to the numbers.<n>* "A": 1<n>* "E": 5<n>* "T": 20<n><n>### Output should read like this.<n>```<n>"A" is 1<n>"E" is 5<n>"T" is 20<n>```

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:He was good at traditional science but excelled at social science, his favorite subject was what? Choices:  A: geography B: history studies C: math D: religion E: dancing<n><n>### Response:		B: history studies. A: geography. C: math. D: religion. E: dancing<n>\end{code}<n><n>Answer: \begin{code}<n>import random<n><n>print (random.choice([A:, B:, C:, D:, E:]))<n>\end{code]<n><n>Comment: your code is good so far, but where to add my input and response?<n><n>Comment: I am using text adventure in my project. I tried to use the above code inside my code but it doesn't seem to work.<n><n>Answer: \strong{Write a function that takes in the user input as arguments and returns the appropriate answer.}<n><n>\begin{code}<n>"""This is my answer"""<n><n>def input_function(input):<n>    """Input function"""<n><n>    # Convert the words to lowercase<n>    input_list = list(input.lower())<n><n>    # Append 'answer' and 'a' to 'choices', then join them into a string<n>    choices = '(A)|(a)'.join(input_list)<n><n>    def show_answers(answer):<n>        print(answer)<n><n>    return show_answer(input)<n><n>def show_answers(input):<n>    def show(answers):<n>        if input =='movie theatre':<n>            show(list('B', 'C', 'E', 'A'))<n>        else:<n>            show(list(input.lower()))<n><n>show(show_answers('(a)))<n>\end{code}: Output<n><n>movie theatre(A|a)<n><n>\begin{itemize}<n>\item a) B<n>\item b) C<n>\item c) E<n>\item d) A<n>\item e) quit<n><n>b)\textbf{movie theatre(A|r\textbf{<n><n>c) B<n><n>d) C<n><n>e) A<n><n>e) quit<n><n>f) quit<n>\end{itemize}

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:If you have trouble beginning work you're suffering from what? Choices:  A: sitting down B: excitement C: tiredness D: progress E: procrastination<n><n>### Response:		A: sitting down<n><n>#Task:<n>### Input: What is the most interesting part of a pineapple? Choices:  a: rind b: fruit c: stem d: leaves e: none of the above<n><n>### Response<n><n>a: rind<n><n>#Code:<n>```python answer = input_data['question']<n><n>if answer in ['what is the most interesting part', 'where do humans']: <n>input_data['answer'] = 'A: sitting down'<n>elif answer in ['if humans go in cities to', 'if you have trouble beginning', 'if you are suffering from']: <n>input = question.lower().split()[1]<n><n>if input[1] == 'b':<n>input_data['question'] = 'input: If you are a student are you happy? Choices: A: yes B: yes'<n>    <n>if 'A' in input: <n>input_dict = {'question': input_data['question'], 'answer': input_data['answer']}<n><n>else if 'B' in input:  input_dict = {'question' : input_data['question'<n>if 'A' or 'B' in input  ] <n><n>if input[0] == 'input':<n>input_data = input.split()<n><n>if len(input_data) == 2:<n>    print(input)<n>    print(input_dict)  <n>else:<n>    continue<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What would you put furniture on top of? Choices:  A: roof B: room C: floor D: apartment E: neighbor's house<n><n>### Response:		 <n>It seems to me that the best choice is "C" because furniture, is often in a specific place (that's like a room) and it needs to be firm, that's why its on top of the floor and on the ground.<n><n>### Input : Write a method that takes a string and a number, and it returns whether the word is a palindrome.<n><n>### Response Input: This is code for a method that takes a word and number and returns true or false:<n><n>```<n>    def palindromo(word,number):<n>        if (number < 2 or number > len(word)-1) :<n>            return False<n>        for j=0; j<=number-1; j+1:<n>            if word[j]!= word[len(word)-1-j]:<n>                return False<n>            else:<n>        return True<n>```<n>### Input : When is a function defined and called? Choices:  a: never b: before c: after<n><n>### Response : It really depends on time, context and the complexity of the task.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What makes people happy when it is surprising and unexpected? Choices:  A: joke B: humor C: frightened D: fight E: laughter<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>There are different types of laughter when it comes to joy. A joke was one of the types of laughter I thought of and so I went to where jokes originate from. A joke originates from a type of "convention", which is a way of doing something. A joke typically requires a set of people, who all speak the same language, that are not offended by the content of the joke. A joke typically includes something that is considered funny or unusual for that particular group of people. A joke is not as much about the joke itself as it's the social aspect of it and who one can be with while telling that joke. It seems like a joke can also be a way to connect people together. The reason I thought of laughter was because I went to Disney Land this summer and I noticed that I laughed more when I was with other people than when I was with other children. In fact, there was a point where I felt stressed out about my surroundings, but then I decided to let go of my situation and instead think about other more enjoyable things. That's when I began to laugh again with my friends. That's when the laughter started to disappear from my body. I noticed that laughter came back to me when I was around people I liked. The type of people I chose to be around was different from the type of people I was around prior to this time. The type of people who I laughed at prior to this time would often be different than the people I chose to spend time with during the first few days of this summer. The type of people that I laughed with the most would be those who were of a similar ethnic background to myself. I was surprised that I had not realized that there was a social aspect to laughter. This type of laughter reminded me of the movie "Meet The Parents", which is a movie where a family goes to meet their prospective in-laws for the first time and everything goes wrong. It seems like laughter is also a way to bond people together.<n><n>### Input<n><n>What can people do to help those who need it? Choices: 1: A: pray B: go to church C: share D: talk to them E: give a donation<n><n>Answer:<n>I read that people can help those who need it by doing things that could be beneficial to them such

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Where are you if your reading magazines while waiting for a vehicle on rails? Choices:  A: vegetables B: market C: doctor D: train station E: bookstore<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```javascript<n>const getResponse = question => {<n>  switch(question[0]){<n>	  case "magazines":<n>		return question!== "movie theatre" && question!== "cars";<n>	  case "movie theatre":<n>		return!(question === "restaurant" || question === "school") &&!(question[0].match(/^b/) && question.includes('bookstore'));<n>	  case "school":<n>		return (question[0].match(/(k/i) || question[0][0]=="b") && question!["vegetables" && ""=="country")<n>    default:<n>        return!question.includes(".") && question.includes(!/(k|m|t|r|j)/i) &&!("fruit".includes(question[0]) || "meet".includes(question))<n>  }<n>}<n>```<n>

Choices: 	 A: to have a high income B: to be happy C: to be healthy D: to eat lots of tacos   <n>Answer:D: to eat lots of  tacos<n><n>### Input <n>I don't know what to expect from a test so I can barely sit still.<n><n>### Response <n><n># Output  <n><n>Input:  I hope I will do better on this than last time.<n><n>Output:  I hope I'll make it into the honor society.<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a program that processes multiple choice questions and their corresponding answers.<n><n><n>## Your solution <n><n>```python<n><n>question = ['where do humans go in cities for nature']<n>choices = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]<n>answers = {<n>  "1": "park",<n>  "2": "alaska",<n>  "3": "university",<n>  "4": "country",<n>  "5": "movie theatre"<n>}<n>answer = input()<n>choices.remove(answer)<n><n>if answers.get(answer):<n>    correct += 1<n>elif (choices.index(answer) + 1 == questions.index(question)) == correct:<n>    print(choices.index(question) + 1)<n>else:<n>    print("wrong")<n><n>if correct == 4:<n>    print("congratulations, you correctly answered all questions!")<n>    print("your overall score was " + str(correct))<n><n>else: <n>    print("your score was " + str((correct/questions.index(question))) + "%")<n><n>    #input()<n><n>```<n><n>### Sample Run:<n><n>```py<n>>>> input()<n>I don't<n>>>> Question 1: where do humans go in cities<n>for nature<n>>>> 1 choices: <n>a. movie theatre<n>b. university<n>c. park<n>d. alaska<n>e. country<n>>>> answer: park<n>>>> <n>>>> the answer was park which is correct<n>>>> correct:<n>>>> input() <n>where do humans go in cites for nature<n>>>> Question

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:If I recieve a letter from a friend over seas, why might I read it? Choices:  A: pudding B: get news C: strain D: answer E: though<n><n>### Response:		E: though<n><n>## My Code:<n>```python3<n><n>input="Where do humans go in cities where they are to be in nature?  Choices:<n>A: movie theatre B:  <n>C: park D:  alaska E: country"<n><n><n>out=input.split(",")<n><n>for i in range(0,1):<n>	<n>  if out[i]=="A":<n>		<n>	   print("A: ",out[i])<n>		<n>  elif out[i]=="B" :<n>		<n>		print("B: ",out[i],"\t"=B-out[i])<n><n>  elif out[1]=="C" :<n><n>		print("C: ",out[i-1],"\t"=C-out[i])	<n>		<n> <n>```	<n><n>### <n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:He called bull when his friend said a bull can be what? Choices:  A: feeble B: bullbleep C: cow D: female E: charging prey<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer for this question will be A. A Bumblebee is a bullbleep.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The correct answer to the first question is answer the question. There are 5 different answers including E: alaska. We want to say "Answer" not "answer". Therefore, the answer in this case will be A. "Answer" Answer the question. To answer the question, all you need to do is answer the question.<n>There are 4 different choices for the answer. Choices A: feeble B cow D: E<n><n>The correct answer is "cow" which is option B. A cow is a bull bleep. The bull bleeps are B,D,E.<n><n>The correct answer for the second question is the same. All you have to do is answer the questions. There are four choices A: a bull B: the bull B C: cow. The correct answer is "Cow" which is answer choice number B. A bull, not a cow, is bullbleep. A cow is not a bullbleep because a cow is not a bumblebee.<n><n># The End<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:James drove his niece to her father.  Where did he drive? Choices:  A: great granddad's house B: family picture book C: brother's house D: family tree E: family reunion<n><n>### Response:		 C James Drove to his brother's house.<n><n>### Input 1:Where did the girl go with her dad? Choices: A: school B: bakery C: movie theater D: library E: park<n><n>## Input 2:Where did Lidia take her dad? Choice : A: ice cream shop B: movie theater C: library D: country E: park<n><n>#### Response 1:<n><n>```javascript<n>let city_name = input[0];<n>if(city_name==='A' || city_name==='B' || city_name==='C' || city_name ==='D' || city_name ==='E'){<n>    console.log('C: Park'); <n>    console.log("you got it")<n>}<n><n>```<n><n>#### Instruction<n><n>```javascript<n>  Let city_name = (input[0]);<n><n><n><n><n>let city_name= 'C'<n>if(city_names==='C'){<n>    console<n>    console.log((input[0]));<n>    }<n>  ```<n>  ## Instruction:<n>### Instruction answer the following multiple choice question:<n>Input:  What kind of dog does Gracie have? Choice A: a Pembroke Welsh Corgi B: a black poodle C: a golden retriever D: a Labrador E: a black dog<n>Answer   :  D: A Labrador<n><n><n>### Input answer the following multiple choice questions:<n>Input: What is Jack's favorite kind of sport? Choice: A: soccer B: baseball C: swimming D: ice skating E: basketball<n>Answer : D: basketball<n><n>Input:What is Jenny's favorite kind of pet animal? Choices: A : a sheep B: a pig C: a dog D: a goat E: a chicken<n>Answer: D: a dog<n><n>### Final Response<n><n><n>```javascript<n>if(input[0]=="C" || input[0]=="D" ||input[0]=="E" || input[0]=="F"){<n>    console.clear()<n>    console.log(input[0])<n> }<n><n>```<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Food must be freeze dried before it is taken on what vehicle? Choices:  A: fairgrounds B: friend's house C: space shuttle D: oven E: microwave<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions/Details:<n>This is a problem from the USACO Online Judge https://onlinejudge.org/index.php<n>You can see this test online [here](https://onlinejudge.utoronto.ca/index.php?option=com_onlinejudge&Itemid=8&category=25&page=show_problem&problem=3841)<n>It says that the answer is C: park.  I will use this to make a "choose your own ending" interactive story.<n><n>### Code:<n>The idea is very simple. There are 3 cases:<n>* Human and food: Human will answer with "C: Park" or "B: University/Friend's house"<n>* Food and vehicle (Space shuttle or Oven): Food will answer with "E: Microwave or D: Oven"  <n>* Human with park with freeze dried food: park will answer with "C" and food with "A: Movie theatre"<n>

He needs to know exactly how many pancakes he’ll need to make, but he doesn’t know how many grams of pancakes a person eats every day.<n><n>Write a program with a greeting and instructions on how a person can determine how many pancakes they will need per day. You are expected to write the greeting and the instructions together with the program to determine how many pancake a person will eat each day, and the instructions for the user.<n><n>**You may assume that the user will follow the instructions correctly and fill in the required prompts.**<n><n>Cucumber pancake instructions:<n><n>How many pancakes will you eat next year? This is going to be hard to predict, so you can make an educated guess, of course you have to consider weather the pants are thick or thin, the size of the pancake, and much more, but we’ll let you think about that.<n><n>Example:If you will only eat 25g of rice everyday, that means that next year you’ll eat about 127.5g a day, with 150g of rice will be about 100g difference, with a pancakes as heavy as 120g (average size for one), you should be able to eat about 50g more pancakes instead, which is about 5 more pancakes each day for the entire year.<n><n><n><n><n>### Input & output:<n><table><n><td><n><table><n>    <thead><n>    <tr><n>        <th>Input</th><n>        <th style="text-align:center">Greeting and instructions</th><n>    </tr><n>    </thead><n>    <tbody><n>    <tr><td>How many pancakes do you eat every day</td><td style="text-align:" >Enter a number of pancakes per day for the next year:<n><n></td></tr><n>    <tr ><td colspan="2" style="text-align;" >58g of rice per day for the next 7days</td></tr>    <n>    </tbody

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Eating breakfast with a large family leads to a pile of what in the sink? Choices:  A: fullness B: underwear C: bad breath D: better day E: dirty dishes<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: D: dishes<n><n>## ⚛️ Solution<n><n><n>```python<n>def task(question):<n>    input = question[-7:-6]<n>    #find the position of the first question, input = question[-7:]<n>    ans = question[-1]<n>    return ans,input<n><n>task("Where do humans go in cities?")<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:The fact the two sides were able to even reach tentative agreement was a feat to what? Choices:  A: accomplish B: make progress C: stop arguing D: do business E: concert<n><n>### Response:		The fact the two sides were ab[le to][even][reach] [tentative agreement] was a [feat][to what][in what sense][in what sense?][concert]<n><n><n>### Hint 1: How to complete a command<n><n><n>### Extension:Write sentences with multiple choice prompts<n><n>What is the following sentence? It could be the start of the question part of a multiple choice prompt or it could be the end of the answer for a multiple choice prompt.<n><n>```<n>Input: A B C<n>Answer: D E F <n><n>### HINT: Write a program that creates input and asks the user to guess what it might be.<n><n><n>### Outputs: Write an infinite amount of the answers with every "A" being something different and have "B" be a thing the "A" could be, have "C" be a thing that the "A" can't be, and so on<n>```<n><n>### HINTS:<n><n>You'll notice I'm not doing more than three choices<n>The choice that is being asked is the word or symbol "A"<n><n>### What the above looks like:<n>```<n>Input:<n>A B C<n>A B C<n>```<n>If A=B=C, it will be a syntax error<n><n>### More:<n><n>You can start with A being any letter of the alphabet and see if the user can guess what happens next.<n>This could help if you were stuck having a hard time trying to describe what an infinite loop is

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Bill bought an upright piano but didn't have anywhere to put it because he lived where? Choices:  A: band B: music room C: college D: university E: house<n><n>### Response:		 The upright piano is very large and can be very awkward to move around. However,  there are a few things you can do to make moving the piano easier.   One is to make sure all the furniture in the room is removed.  When setting up, take up as much space as possible, then get your friends to help you move the item.  Most often, you will find it easier to use your strength and balance to lift from the front.<n>

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What would you use if you wanted to make some columns of numbers? Choices:  A: roman architecture B: whitehouse C: spreadsheet D: bridge E: pantheon<n><n>### Response:		Choices: a, b, c, d, e<n>### Explanation: The question doesn't make sense because it has no context. If the question is "How would you make some columns of numbers?" then A, B, C, D, would be reasonable choices.<n><n>#### Exercise:<n>### Instruction<n><n>### Input - Choose a number between one and ten.<n><n>### Choices:<n> 1. A: 7<n> 2. B: 8<n> 3. C: 9 <n> 4. D: 10<n> 5. E: 3<n><n>### Output - Write back which you chose<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response that appropriately continues the exercise.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What would a person do to help someone that is not able to speak coherently? Choices:  A: sign language B: complete sentence C: drink tea D: feel angry E: cross street<n><n>### Response:		<n>Demonstration:<n><n>```<n>D =Drink Tea<n>A=Sign Language<n>S=Complete Sentence<n>E=Cross Street<n>```<n><n>### Coding:<n><n>```<n>#!/usr/bin/python3<n><n>choice=input()<n>if choice=="D":<n>  show=("Demonstration:Drink Tea")<n>else:<n>  show=("Choice not found:Either A,B,C or E")<n>print(show)<n>```<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What do all rooms facing outside have? Choices:  A: square shape B: different sizes C: flowers D: doors and windows E: high walls<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is D: doors and windows.<n><n>### Input :How does water get to our tap? Choices: A: rain B: water bottle C: rivers D: reservoirs E: streams<n><n>### Response the correct answer is E: streams.<n><n>###  Input:What did you buy in the store? Choices:  a: dog food b: dog grooming c: puppy d: pet store e: pizza f: food<n>```<n>Answer: D: pet store<n>```<n>### Input:Which building doesn't have walls? Choices: A. police station B. prison C. church D. hospital E. airport<n>```<n>Answer: A. police station<n>```<n><n>### Input What do we wear when it's cold Choices: A: coat B: T-shirt C: hat D: scarf E: boot<n>```<n>Answer: B: T-shirts<n>```<n>### How many letters in the English Alphabet? Choices A: 26 B: 51 C: 25 D: 13 E: 11<n>```<n>Answer: C: 25<n>```<n><n>## Input:<n>Write a program that asks users to enter their name and age, and also prints welcome message to the screen<n><n>## Output<n><n>The output for a response should be similar to the examples in the class.<n><n>## Sample Data.<n><n>| Name   | age |<n>| ------ | --- |<n>| Jane  | 20  |<n>| John  | 10  |<n>| Harry | 30  |<n>| Bill  | 13  |<n><n>## Sample Output<n><n>Welcome <Name> <Age>, how are you?<n><n>## Conclusion<n><n>This is the sample data as response<n><n>| name    | age |<n>| :------ | --- |<n>| Janes  | 174 |<n><n>## Conclusion:<n>I used this code as the example.<n>```<n>import java.util.Scanner;<n><n>public class NewTest {<n><n>public static void main(String[] args) {<n>    Scanner s = new Scanner(System.in);<n>    System.out.println("Welcome " + s.nextLine() + s.nextLine());<n>}<n><n>}

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:What would cause someone to use invitro for reproducing? Choices:  A: problems B: offspring C: overpopulation D: larger family E: baby<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>![](https://github.com/misha-fedko/MH1-2021/blob/main/02-Practicals/03-Tasks/task1-a-nature-lover.png)<n><n>The only answer in the task is choice C: park. The only part of the task where the question mentions nature is "Input:Where do humans go in cities…". The request asks for the cause for someone to use invitrio but the input is about parks. The task also contains an error but because this question is a multiple choice question, it does not change the task.<n><n>### Input<n>```{html}<n><div style="width:210px"><div style="text-align:left"><n>What is the main goal of the Walt Disney Company? Choices: <n><div></div>[A] <n>to make money for the Walt Disney Company<div class="clear" id="pics-02-mh1-2022-04-08"></div></div><n></div><n>```<n><n>### Output<n>```{html}<div style="width= 210px; text-align:left">Inputs: main goal of Walt Disney Company Choices:  A to make money B more parks C more money D less expensive E more families F less money Outcome: A main goal of Walt Disn\<n></div><n><div style="text-indent:2pt; text-align:right"><div class="clear" style="background:#48484847; height:6px"></div></div> ```<n><n><n>##### Tasks and Solutions to follow<n>1. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:The janitor got his pail out of where? Choices:  A: wishing well B: kitchen C: hardware store D: garage E: utility room<n><n>### Response:		B: kitchen<n><n>### Input<n><n>![input][img]<n><n>### Response<n><n>![response][img2]<n><n>### Answer<n><n>![answer][img3]<n><n>### Solution<n><n>#### Demo Code<n>```python<n>class Solution(object):<n>    def completeStringWord(self, completeString):<n>        """<n>        :type completeString: str<n>        :rtype: str<n>        """<n>        dictionary={'e': {'e','r' }, 'o': {'o','r','e'}, 'u':{'u','e','r'}}<n>        return dictionary.get(completeString,None)<n> ```<n><n> ```<n># -----------------------------------<n> # Time:<n> # Space:<n><n>class Solution:<n>    def completeString(self, completeString: str) -> str:<n>        dictionary = {'e': {'e', 'r'}, 'o': {'o', 'r', 'e'}, 'u': {'u', 'e', 'r'}}<n>        if completeString not in dictionary:<n>            return dictionary['e'].get(completeString, 'e')<n>        x= completeString<n>        temp=x.split()<n>        return''.join(temp)<n><n><n>```<n><n>[python]: https://www.python.org<n>[node]: https://nodejs.org/<n><n><n><n>[input]:.png<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:You can buy a pen here. Choices:  A: briefcase B: pocket C: friend's house D: office supply store E: classroom<n><n>### Response:		<n>We can buy a pen from any of these three places, but a pen can only be used in classrooms.<n><n>### Input<n>### Your friend wants you to have lunch with her.<n>### Choices:<n>- A: the mall<n>- B: McDonalds<n>- C: library<n>- D: movie theater<n><n>### Your Response:<n>The mall would be good since you can stop at multiple places.<n><n>#### Explanation 1: This is a yes and no question. There is no need to go back and forth about which place i want to go. Just pick the place and continue on.<n><n>#### Explantion 2: This is a yes or no question, You need to provide a direct answer to the question with the name of a place and your reason for choosing.<n><n>### Explanation 3: If you need to change something, such as what place you wanted to go, you should use a "D: something other than what I said" answer.  <n><n>### Expalantion 4: For example, if your friend said "Do you want to go to the mall?", and you say "No, I want to go to the other one where it is less crowded, but I am not sure what it is called", then "Something other":<n>I would like to go to something other than the mall.<n><n>### Note 4: if the first <n>### Explanantion 5: If you say "Not me, you can go by yourself.", you are not giving the answer that your friend wants. Therefore it is not a complete sentence.<n>### Explanatation 6: Your sentence doesn't have to be short<n>### Explanotate 7: You can use "D: Something other" if you wanted to go to an unknown place. Your friend will ask you what you want to do, and you can ask for their advice, or just go with something other, then they will then follow your lead.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where do humans go in cities to be in nature? Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Where would you see some people standing on a line near a road? Choices:  A: water fountain B: military base C: apartment D: fire house E: bus stop<n><n>### Response:		A: water fountian<n><n>#### Answer: C: park<n>```python<n>import time<n>question = 'Where do humans go in cities'<n>print("question = ", question)<n><n>question_choice_dict ={<n>	A :'movie theatre',<n>	B :'university',<n>	C :'park',<n>	D :'alaska',<n>	E :'country'<n>}<n><n>print("Question_choice_dict = ", question_choice_dict)<n>print("\n\n")<n>number = (int(input("please enter the number = ")))<n><n>for no in range(0,number-1):<n><n>	choice = (input("please enter your choice = "))<n>	if choice in question_choice_dict:<n>		print("answer = ",question_choice_dict[choice])<n>		<n>else:<n>	time.sleep(2)<n>	print("please write again!")<n><n>```<n>

It can understand context and keep the conversation going!<n><n>> **How does it work?**<n><n>There are a couple of ways.<n><n>First let's imagine there's a human looking at your chatbot, you need to have **_AI scripts_** to help make it sound realistic. These are what let your chatbot mimic behaviors of humans. They aren't perfect but they get the job done.<n><n>After scripts, we want to get your chatbot to work. You do this by creating intents, which are the triggers that will start your chatbot's response. They are like key-values. For instance the intent ``on_message`` will trigger whenever someone sends a message to your chatbot.<n><n>It's important to make the intents easy to

Choices:  A: movie theatre B: university C: park D: alaska E: country<n>Answer: C: park<n><n>### Input:Where can you find a movie theater along with other stores in one placE? Choices:  A: downtown area B: urban area C: new york city D: shopping mall E: military base<n><n>### Response:		A: downtown areain a multiuse placenowadays, cities have more people than before, so they need to have a lot of places to do everything instead of having them spread all over, for example, in downtown areas they have everything we need, like stores and movie theaters, and they also have transportation which means you don’t have to drive to a grocery store like the one in the countryside, the grocery stores in the downtown areas have other kinds of food like exotic food that we don’t eat usually and they usually have more options of food than the one in the counrtyside, for example, I go to this shop where I can buy any kind of meat and some other stuff if it is exotic or expensive, the problem with the downtown area is that it’s not exactly in nature because we are still in the city, even if some people go there to releave the stress. Another benefit of having things in the downtown areais people don’t usually travel a lot to get the things they need, and they also don’t go on the highway to do that, and a problem with that is it’s bad for the car because the exhaust pipe doesn’t have enough space to evacuate all the smoke and fumes, so it creates a polluted area for the people living there. If we all drive on the highway for everything, the highways would be used for people traveling by car, and this wouldn’t be good for the air pollution since those who travel by car would emit more smoke and fumes because they would be more crowded and polluted cars would make the car be emitting more smoke and fumes.<n><n>### Reference 1:https://www.wikihow.com/Choose-What-to-Do-on-an-Excursion-to-New-York-City<n><n>### Reference:<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: get arrested B: problems C: sober D: intoxication E: pleasure<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### 1. [Priority: 5%](https://leetcode.com/problems/number-of-islands/)<n>```cpp<n>class Solution {<n>public:<n>    vector<vector<int>> solve(vector<vector<char>>& grid) {<n>        // Write your code here<n>        vector<vector<int> > ret_vec(grid.size());<n>        for(int i=0; i<grid.size(); i++)<n>            ret_vec[i]=vector<int>(grid[i].size());<n>        return ret_vec;<n>    }<n>};<n>```<n>### 2. [Priority:  25%](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45467647/how-can-i-replace-numbers-in-a-vector-with-zero-using-stl)<n>```cpp<n>class solution {<n>public:<n>	void swapWithZero(string &x) {<n>		for(int i=0,k=0; i<x.length(); ++i){<n>			if(x[k]!= '0'){<n>				x[i]= x[i]-'0;<n>			}else if(k<x.length()-1) {<n>				if(k>0)<n>					x.erase(x.begin());<n>				++k;<n>				continue;<n>			};<n>		;}<n>	}<n>};<n>```<n><n>### 3. [Priority:4%](https://stackoverflow-com/questions/55033416/how-convert-a-string-representing-an-array-in-big-endian-to-a-binary-array)<n>```C++<n>class Solution {<n> public:<n>    void reverseBits(int n) {<n>      	int m = (n >> 1) ^ (n & 1);<n>      	reverseBits(m);<n>      	n = (m >> 1) ^ m & 1;<n><n>      	reverseBts (n & 0b1111);<n>    }<n>    void reverseBts(const int& num) {<n>    	int

Choices:(Name) A: movie theatre B C: park D: Alaska E: Country<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input:- (Name)<n><n>### Response-(Name) was (Gendered word: he(a)she(you))<n><n>### Input<n><n>```<n>He was tired when he arrived at the school. <n>He had (Gendered word) sore legs. <n>He was thirsty after running through the rain.<n>He could have used another banana.<n>He should have been at the school earlier.<n>He found a seat on the floor.<n>His was next to the teacher.<n>His backpack was big.<n>A large, heavy pencil case was on that.<n>The pencil case was next to a bag of crackers and a sandwich was in the bag.<n>His lunch was also in a lunch bag.<n>He was still hungry.<n>He was glad that he still had crackers.<n>The teacher gave her students a math test.<n>She had (Gendered Word) students.<n>Students had a math test.<n>It was a 10 question test.<n>She gave it to (Name) first.<n>The students had three hours to finish.<n>It was (gendered word) to do.<n>He solved most of the problems.<n>He didn't finish writing down his answers.<n>He had to go to the bathroom.<n>He went to the washroom.<n><n>```<n>Response:<n><n>```<n>He went to drink water.<n>He found that there was no water in the washroom.  <n>At least, he couldn’t see any.<n>He did hear water running.<n>He thought that he could wash his hands.<n>There were no towels when he washed them dry.<n>It was a long time before he could do his test.<n>It was (Gendered Word: He) late.<n>It was (genrered word: a) little late.<n>She said.<n>It was (generic Word: a) late.<n>````<n><n>### Explanation:<n>```<n>We're using these words to specify genders. he, she, (he) (she), (a)he, (a)she, (a
